title: Planet Data

author: Elena Simperl, School of Electronics and Computer Science, University of Southampton

segmentation: Sell AM.
Planet Data is one of the.
Initiatives that supports this event.
So I thought at least some of you might want to hear what it is about.
So I prepared a short presentation.
It's So what is it?
It's a network of excellence that is funded in the.
5th Call of the 7th Framework Program.

It started in October 2010 and it had it started with eight partners from various communities, three to be more precise from the Semantic Technologies Area, Free University of Berlin STI Innsbruck Khits from databases.
EPS fell from and then CWI from Dayton Web mining, GSI and UPM being somehow at the intersection between semantics and central management.
And the aim is to bring these people in the same project for four years and see what comes out of it.
Um?
Some of the.
Some of the.
Topics that we are addressing in the in the project.
So it's a network of excellence, which means that there is some research, but there is also a fair amount of effort dedicated to integrating existing efforts in it and and research results into a.
Coherent framework there is also effort dedicated to.
Training the community.
Organizing dissemination events, community building and so on and so forth.

Now topic wise, what Planet data is aiming at is to provide techniques and technology that help or make the data that is published out there as RDF or in a structured format more useful for potential applications and to do so there are basically 2 lines of work for RDF datasets that are already there, we look.
Into questions of quality assessment as well as provenance and access control.
On top of that, we want to encourage the publication and exposure of other types of data, as RDF, in particular streams, and the work that address presented is in this in this context.
Um?

Typically also for for the kind of effort that I mentioned before we internetwork Rex Alliance of bringing existing pieces of work together and supporting the community, is the work that we're doing on elaborating best practices for various aspects in the data management lifecycle.
As well as.
Some some training events, in particular summer school, the SWC Summer School that that was launched very successfully this year.
Um?
And some other things.
In particular, we want to do have to look into new forms of scientific publishing, and we want to launch Video Journal on on topics related to the planet data.
And last but not least, there is this thing called Planet data programs by.
Which we can we?
Broaden the scope of the consortium by allocating a third of our budget to partners that can join the consortium model later point in time.
Following an open called, we plan to have two of such calls, calls.
One of them was already organized and it is completed.
We had 36 proposal submissions from small consortia from 1 two to three.

Organizations requesting for something around 3 million euros for the 300,000, that's that we had the whole thing was organized like like a mini call within EU According to the to the same guidelines and we're happy to welcome 4 new institutions from October this year that will work on applications in the environmental.

Area or traffic management as it is the case for computer science into from Norway and came I from the Open University and looking into different ways to address quality assessment or repair within within datasets.
As it is the case for Jeffrey L in.
The area of urban computing.
If this was as convincing as I thought it is, or it was, I welcome.
All partners institutions in this room.
That are not yet part of Planet data to drop us an email, look at our website and join the network.
Besides the next call that will be issued next year.
We also have this schema.
The schema of associate partners that is much more flexible is not related to any schedules, project submissions or alike.
Where by becoming associate partner you basically have access to all results of the network, can participate in the meeting.

Collaborate to to whatever activities were planning and we're happy to say that the concept seems to have been received positively in the community, and after nine months of after the project has started, we have more than 15 institutions of various kinds that are already part of the network.
That was all.
Any controversies?
Did you use the right font?
Um?
Opinions?
Not good.
OK. OK, any questions?
Any other questions?
Well then, for once I take this as a very positive result of the presentation.
